input: My final exam is near, but my mental health is getting worse. Any advice?
output_expected: Therapist here. No worries. There is a lot of things you can do to keep youself calm, depending on what works for you. Music therapy - youtube or spotify relaxing and calming music to help you reduce your heart rate and calm your breathing if your anxiety gets bad. Take your time with it. Journal - write down your anxious thoughts. what worries you the most, is anything else bothering you, are you catastrophizing? Talk it out - do you have a family member, friend or classmate that would be willing to listen to you vent and air your concerns? Therapy - if its within finanical reason, consider speaking to a therapist Dissociation - I love using this technique. You know that little voice in your head that tell you you will fail, there is not enough time, you will get kicked out of school, your parents will be so dissapointed etc etc? I cannot stress this enough, this voice is not you Just becuase you hear it in your head does not mean it is true. A good method for this is one of my favorites. Imagine for a moment that you are sat on a sofa, and this voice in your head saying all this negativity is another person sat with on on this couch. Listen to them talk. Listen to how they ramble on and on about all this negative stuff. Its getting tiring, annoying and frustrating. So walk away It sounds silly to some, but making this kind of distinction of "I am ME and I am NOT my thoughts" is an incredibly useful tool. Meditation or self hypnosis - as a hypnotherapist, i may be bias here, but hear me out Meditation and self hypnosis is an incredible tool to ease mental health and stress issues. There are many guided tools available online, you just have to find one that speaks to you. I hope this helps you

input: Who does mental illness affect?
output_expected: It is estimated that mental illness affects 1 in 5 adults in America, and that 1 in 24 adults have a serious mental illness. Mental illness does not discriminate; it can affect anyone, regardless of gender, age, income, social status, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or background. Although mental illness can affect anyone, certain conditions may be more common in different populations. For instance, eating disorders tend to occur more often in females, while disorders such as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder is more prevalent in children. Additionally, all ages are susceptible, but the young and the old are especially vulnerable. Mental illnesses usually strike individuals in the prime of their lives, with 75 percent of mental health conditions developing by the age of 24. This makes identification and treatment of mental disorders particularly difficult, because the normal personality and behavioral changes of adolescence may mask symptoms of a mental health condition. Parents and caretakers should be aware of this fact, and take notice of changes in their child's mood, personality, personal habits, and social withdrawal. When these occur in children under 18, they are referred to as serious emotional disturbances (SEDs).

input: What treatment options are available?
output_expected: Just as there are different types of medications for physical illness, different treatment options are available for individuals with mental illness. Treatment works differently for different people. It is important to find what works best for you or your child.

input: Where can I go to find a support group?
output_expected: Many people find peer support a helpful tool that can aid in their recovery. There are a variety of organizations that offer support groups for consumers, their family members and friends. Some support groups are peer-led, while others may be led by a mental health professional.

input: What is mental health?
output_expected: We all have mental health which is made up of our beliefs, thoughts, feelings and behaviours.

input: What should I do if I am worried about a friend or relative?
output_expected: This may depend on your relationship with them. Gently encouraging someone to seek appropriate support would be helpful to start with.

input: Is it fair to ask may partner if he can refrain from talking about calories? My partner is an endurance athlete and has been increasing his training intensity, frequency, etc. It is happened a handful of times now where, around meal time, he will reference how many calories he burned per his app or whatever he uses to program his workouts. For context, he references calories in this context like, “I am ready to eat because I am so unusually hungry, which makes sense because I apparently burned x calories during my workout”. He is aware of my ED history and has been supportive so far. I want to ask him not to talk about calories in front of me because it is honestly triggering. That said, I do not know how to approach this conversation or if it is even fair of me to make this request. TIA for any advice or support.
output_expected: Yes, it is totally fine to mention to him about how you feel. Personally, I find calorie counting to be very harmful unless a medical/nutritional professional is involved. Since he knows about your ED history I am sure he will understand and refrain from speaking about calories around you. But do not tell him to stop completely instead suggest using other words to replace the numeric values or the word calories itself For example: 1. man I am so hungry, I worked out a lot today! 2. I need to increase my food intake 3. My intake and exercise are not adding up, I will need to make a few adjustments to my diet/gym routine All these examples replace the need to mention calories or a numeric value. I hope this helped.

input: I need advice on how to approach my depressed girlfriend. I am seeing her tonight for the first time in a few days. Last time I saw her, I noticed her teeth were unclean, to the point there was physical build up on them. She is my girlfriend, so obviously she is going to want a kiss, but I highly doubt she is brushed them since then. If that is the case, what is the best way to tell her I do not want to kiss her if she has not brushed her teeth in weeks? I need to set my hygienic boundaries but I do not want to offend her or make her feel bad and judged.
output_expected: There is no agreeable way telling someone he smell. But if you do not, you let her roam free with a bad breath, that can make her be ostracised from social life. So tell her, it is for her own good. Be respectuous, just tell her the odor from her mouth make you feel bad, that is all. Of course she will not take it well but only the truth could make things better.

input: Partners drug test kit was positive. I am seeking advice. My partner of 10 years has always struggled with addiction. Heroin in the past, opioids and benzos etc. He is currently getting monthly buvidal (Buprenorphine) injections at his doctor.. I have been trying to support him as much as I can. We have been through a lot and I adore him. He is not a bad human, he is a hard working beautiful human that is struggling. Last night I took a drink from a water bottle in my car, that he had bought that day - it tasted like chemicals and I felt strange after. Upon asking him, he denyed anything (maybe It was in my head). I got an at home drug test kit this morning and tested the bottle/ water. It tested positive for opioids and methadone. I confronted him and he said he f'd up.. I do not know what to do.. it is the looking me in the eyes and lying.. I feel like such a fool. We are actively trying to conceive.. I am feeling numb as it is just a repeat cycle of dishonesty. The trust is broken. I do not know who to turn to for support.. for either of us. I have attended appointments with his doctor, I did not think opioids were supposed to have an affect when on the injections.. that taking drugs were pointless. I do not know what to do anymore.. I am exhausted by it.. and I am fully aware he is too.
output_expected: I am so sorry this is happening. You cannot make decisions for him, but you can tell him that his decisions have a direct impact on you and your relationship with him. Tell him you will support him however you can, but that you cannot support him making these decisions.

input: Is it appropriate to request that my partner refrain from bringing up calories? My partner has been upping the volume, frequency, and other aspects of his training. He has mentioned how many calories he expended according to his app or whatever he uses to schedule his workouts a few times recently, usually around mealtime. He is aware of my past with eating disorders and has so far shown support. Since talking about calories in front of me is actually triggering, I want to ask him to refrain. Having said that, I'm not sure how to start this conversation or even if my request is reasonable. TIA for any assistance or counsel.
output_expected: Yes, it is totally fine to mention to him about how you feel. Personally, I find calorie counting to be very harmful unless a medical/nutritional professional is involved. Since he knows about your ED history I am sure he will understand and refrain from speaking about calories around you. But do not tell him to stop completely instead suggest using other words to replace the numeric values or the word calories itself For example: 1. man I am so hungry, I worked out a lot today! 2. I need to increase my food intake 3. My intake and exercise are not adding up, I will need to make a few adjustments to my diet/gym routine All these examples replace the need to mention calories or a numeric value. I hope this helped.

input: How should I approach my depressed girlfriend? I need advice. Tonight is the first time I've seen her in a few days. When I last saw her, I observed that her teeth were so filthy that there was actual buildup on them. She is my girlfriend, so it goes without saying that she will want to kiss me, but I seriously doubt she has kissed them afterwards. If that's the case, how can I tell her if she hasn't washed her teeth in days that I don't want to kiss her? While I must establish my own boundaries for hygiene, I do not want to hurt her feelings or make her feel terrible or criticized.
output_expected: There is no agreeable way telling someone he smell. But if you do not, you let her roam free with a bad breath, that can make her be ostracised from social life. So tell her, it is for her own good. Be respectuous, just tell her the odor from her mouth make you feel bad, that is all. Of course she will not take it well but only the truth could make things better.

input: Partners' drug test kit returned a positive result. I need some guidance. For the past ten years, my spouse has battled addiction. In the past, heroin, opioids, benzos, etc. He currently receives monthly injections of buvidal (buprenorphine) from his physician. I've been doing everything I can to help him. Since the circle of dishonesty is just repeated, I am feeling numb. Trust has been betrayed. For either of us, I am unsure of who to turn to for help. I've been to visits with his doctor since I didn't believe opioids should have an effect while being injected and that taking medicines was useless. I'm at a loss on what to do now. It has worn me out.
output_expected: I am so sorry this is happening. You cannot make decisions for him, but you can tell him that his decisions have a direct impact on you and your relationship with him. Tell him you will support him however you can, but that you cannot support him making these decisions.

input: Make this
output_expected: Sorry, I did not understand you. Could you explain it better?
